titleStmt.title: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified in the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: The road led to the old graves, to the stones where the
old pagan English had offered sacrifice. The peasants still

went that way, in
spir ng spring , summer and winter, by instinct.

The old Gods
stil still lay hidden beneath the new.
Even if they were now nameless, it was to them do them
homage, to win crops, husbands, health, that the
peasants came at the proper season in spring summer and
winter.
It is the printing press that we owe their

preservation. "After that I had accomplished and
finsihed finished

divers histories" Caxton wrote in
41470 1470 in the preface
to the Morte DArthur, "many noble and divers gentlemen

l.quote: of this realm of England came and demanded me many and oft
times ..... to imprint the history of the said noble king
and conqueror King Arthur, and of his knights with the
history of the San greal and of the death and ending of

p.l: the said Arthur." The twenty one books of the Morte DArthur

preserve what lay
benea th beneath , the house, in the field
Ther there we tap into the deep reservoir
of common belief that lay behind somewhere [beneath?]the peasant and the noble.

The
legnd legend was still alive in the nineteenth century.
"...folks do say" said a peasant at Cadbury that on the

l.quote:
night of the full moon King
Arthus Arthur and his men ride round
the hill, and their horses are shod with silver..."

p.l: A silver horseshoe, Leland says, was found in
time at Camelot. It is in Malorys pages that we hear the
voice of that anon who murmuring in the mind of King and Queen and
peasant, They remembered how the old King
and his knights went their ways through the wild woods seek
ing adventure. When Caxton himself doubted. Nosuch a man, he
objected, had ever lived. But the nobles were positive,
they said that you could see Gawaines skull at Dover
and the Round Table at Winchester and in "in other places

l.quote: Launcelots sword and many other things.

p.l: The book itself represents Caxtons scepticism, and the
nobles faith. It is half fable, half fact. There is London,
and Carlisle and St Albans; there is the Archbishop of
Canterbury and St Pauls. But the roads lead past London to
castles where Knights lie in prison; down the roads ride
Queens on white mules; Morgan le Fay turns suddenly to
stone; and a hand rises from a lake holding Excalibur.

In the
canfdour candour with
wh h which it is told, it is a childs story.
But the the child has lived for centuries. It has not our pers

spective. The inventories, the catalogues are
mad made with

a childs
partciularity particularity . The clear eye sees definitely and
without exaggeration. Beauty is in the thing itself, not i
in the writers manipulation. So he went in and searched

quote.l: chamber from chamber to chamber, and found his bed, but she
was not there; then Balin looked into a fair little garden
and under a laurel tree he saw her lie upon a quilt of

green samite and a
kmight knight with her, and under their heads
grass and herbs."

p.l: But It is not a childs world; it is a world before self

consciousness has raised
i s its mirror. The men and women are

angualr angular , gigantic; freed from
somthing something impure; yet sin

tarnished,
acqauinted acquainted with sorrow, corrupt, in the midst of
this fresh landscape, remembering,
We lose our bearings following these Knights and ladies;

to live in
t is this
prehistroic prehistoric land we must
sehd shed many habits

of
thoght thought ; but after all it is not an unreal world;
a fabricated world; it still exists in us, deep sunk,
savage, primitive; m remembered.

Of the writer, nothing is
knonw known . He is not He still is merged

disnctin c distinct from
hsi ook his book . It is still the anonymous voice

speaking
anonysmously anonymously generally
hat that the
lsiener listener already

hald half knows, or
rmemebers remembers . The
lsiener listener hears the voice
partly in himself; as it comes from the man at the back

door who has been travelling in
trange strange parts
acrsoos across the

marsh across the flood to
r mind remind the
peasnt peasant and the noble
of the world that was before them. And still the dream

lingered; for the
peasnts peasants
In the great house and the cottage this half articulate

voice murmured of old gods
a d and kings and
inihgts knights
The well and the tree were still haunted. King Arthur

the
foreste s foresters said in the thirteenth
cnetury century , ;;;"about

noon or
midngiht midnight when the moon is
sufulland full and shining
[we?] often see an array of hunters with dogs and sound of

horns who
ins anser answer to the
enwuirers enquirers says

yhat that they are of the
hosuehold household and fellowship of

p.l:
King
Art ur Arthur ." Along the roads from town to town

from house to
ouse house , came the
minstresl minstrels the jugglers and

the impudent bardes.
whil While for those who could read it,

Caxtons book
tol told the old stories set out in print.

then
late later the instinct to enact, to impersonate
hat they believed imagined came into existence.
Even the King and Queen shared the it, and must have

their actors or
minstersl minstrels to
vie give body vie tongue to this

hidden
insticnt instinct [illeg.]. The
acror actor was
despied despised ;
did he not make use of his body? and did he not,

feeling himself an
otcast outcast , use the
outiders outsiders privilege of
irrepsoneible irresponsible mockery? But the Kings and Queens tolerated

him, as
to rate tolerate those who say what we are too proud

to admit. Even the church men had to a re aware that the
Gids Gods
or to make use of his gift to If they could they constrained

the
c ors actors and the
da cers dancers
t to put off their
l evea leaves
na d and bells
and dress themselves as the sacred figures in a miracle play.

But the churchmen did their best to
prvent prevent them.
The printing press brought the past into existence.

It also brought into existence, seen
agoanst against the back

rgound ground of the past. And it brough by degrees the
indivual individual

into existence--the
indi idual individual who looking back sees himself the man who is separate from his book.
against the background. The individual emerges

at last. He is a chronicler in the [illeg.]His name is
Holingshed Holinshed ; it is also
Har ison Harrison .
Harrison tells us that he has books; and a mastiff;

and digs
i in the ground for Roman coins. He tells us that he

has
nev never been more than forty miles from radwinter in Essex.

The individual, still much
sumplified simplified , but still no longer

nameless,
emrges emerges . He is losing his ambiguity.
the present is becoming visible. Harrison sees the present
moment (15 ) against the settled orderly past.

The present looks
degenrate degenerate , raw, against that past.

It was at half past two in
th the afternoon that the

trumpets
dounded sounded and the flag flew over the Theatre.
The playhouse was open to the sky. A penny or twopence was
the price of a seat. There was no scenery; but the walls
were painted; and the actors were richly dressed, according
to one spectator in the cast off robes of the nobles, sold

by their servants. What other amusement
as was there in the
afternoon, for the gentlement of the court, the of the Inns
of Court, for the numbers of captains and soldiers about
London? Only the amusements that Latimer deplored;
carding, dicing, gaming, following of [whores?] and
harlots and drinking. The river audience came from

the
drowded crowded festering little streets that round St Pauls
where the buried smelt so strong. The river was crowded with

wherries ferrying them across: The riverside people
depnded depended

upon their fares. The flag flew; the trumpets
dsounded sounded ; and
audince audience crowded into the open playhouse, clustered round the
stage; and heard:

quote.l: Brother Cosroe, I find myself aggrieved,

Yet insufficient
yto to express the same;
For it requires a great and thundering speech

p.l: At last the voice speaks from the actual body of one man.

xmxmxmxmxm.And the
wolrd world became visible. Egypt, Libya;

Persia; Greece. It unrolled itself time; and the armies of
gr at great
Kings; and plains; and palaces. There is no abstraction any
longer. All is visible tangible, audible. The words

ords Words seem to swell and stretch and tumble over
themslves themselves
in the effort to give body to this vast universe.
They can scarcely contain all they would bring forward.

quote.l:
The
sprung spring is hindered by your smothering host,
For neither rain can fall upon the earth,
Nor sun reflex his virtuous beams thereon,
The ground is mantled with such multitudes.

p.l: Abrtactions Abstractions withdraw themselves. All is The Kings and
Emperors stride forth, palpable, coloured, strident. The ae
They are hewn, mob- monstrous, brilliantly painted;
but they movel they speak. They emerge like great moths,
stillcreased still creased and damp, shaking their wings in splendid
aburd absurd hyperboles and raptures and The great names crash
like cymbals

quote.l: tell him, , Lord thy Lord the Turkish Emperor,

Dre d Dread Lord of Afric,
Eruope Europe and Asia,

Great king and
conqueor conqueror of
Greacia Graecia ,
The ocean, Terrene, and the coal-black sea....

p.l:
It is bombast, it is
pagenatry pageantry ; it is hyperbole. And yet

surpass common sense;
clah clash and rebound:

quote.l:
W se Whose eyes are brighter than the lamps of
Haevan Heaven ,

And speech more
pl sant pleasant than sweet harmony!

that with thy looks canst
clclear clear the
datkemed darkened sky,
And calm the rage of thundering Jupiter...

p.l:
He is beyond the provinces of plain
pseech speech ,
revelling in some untouched garden of untouched blooms;

picking
plaucking plucking words, and strewing them.

There is no shadow; all is gold and
urple purple .
Yet in the very pitch and height of this extravagance,
the theme he veers,

quote.l: So poets say my lord.
An And tis a pretty toy to be a poet..

del.l: So distended with rapture, the tune changes

p.l: Could he stop, he would cutdeeper. But there is no pause;

no shadow. The
pagenat pageant [illeg.]. The horses neigh.

Kings and
Empeors Emperors emerge. Battles are fought. Blood flows.

And all over this
multitidionous multitudinous splendour broods
agedy tragedy
Do we foretell We forbode. We behold the thing as We [illeg.] there

spectacle. There is the end to come. Meanwhile, let us
boas boast
and triumph.

quote.l: Our souls, whose faculties can comprehend
The wondrous architecture of the world,
And measure very wandering planets course

Still climbing after
knowlede knowledge
infinute infinite ,

And always moving as the restless
spe eres spheres ,
Well us to wear ourselves, and never rest...

p.l:
That is the
meldy melody the marching song of this brave
septacle spectacle . And yet, as if the poet slipped the noose of his

audiences,
releved relieved himself of its pressure for one moment,
we hear:

amid the
so nding sounding brass:

quote.l:
What is
beautym beauty, saith my sufferings, then?
If all the pens that ever poets held

Had fed the
feelingsx feelings of their masters' thoughts,

If all these had made one poems
riod period ,

And all combined in
b auty's beauty's worthiness,

Yet should there hover in their
estless restless heads
one thought, one wonder grace, one wonder, at the least,
Which into words no virtue can digest

p.l: It is a break; a strain out of keeping; to be recalled at once

a sign that the dramatist is separate from the
anony ous anonymous play
maker; There is no little language to put on Kings lips;

so that he cannot as yet
amalgamante amalgamate naturally

the thought and the action. The audience, the
shopr keeprs shopkeepers

apprentices
insoored ensured not
relfection reflection blood [illeg.], but action,
of the undifferentiated gluttonous word greedy mass.
It is inspired by the common voice, demanding great names,

simple
outl nes outlines ; clamour and
virtory victory and death; not the
singe single

subtlety of one soul.
Refelction Reflection breaks off from
